comments.commentBody: It's the White Queen (Through the Looking-Glass, ch. 5). The White Queen was slovenly and scatterbrained; the Red queen was a martinet.
I heard that, and the other element that resonated was the feeling "We are not safe".  Those interviews were disturbing.

This is a problem for our country  in Congress. These backward States with small populations have way too much power!  Think of Inohofe of Oklahoma bringing a snowball to refute climate change!  Okiowa should share 1 seat in Congress.

In listening to the NPR story on Friday where Iowan Republicans at theRepublican caucus were interviewed as to who they support.  The responses of these people remind me of Lewis Carroll's 'Through The Looking Glass', where the Red Queen proudly proclaims "I've believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast" without ever realizing the degree of ignorance, naivety, and gullibility required of such a feat.  What's a Republican candidate to do in order to gain their votes if not to pander to such a poorly educated bunch of rubes?  These people seriously thought that to elect a democratic president automatically meant their guns were going to be taken from them.  No question about it.
Make that "EVERY single mother" (or, better, "every unmarried mother").

I grew up in Florida and have lived in Massachusetts for the last 35 years. My husband (who is Greek) and I love the Cracker Barrel. The (multicultural) staff are friendly; there's cool, old fashioned candy and lots of corny stuff for sale. And, it's good food. The grits are made fresh. The biscuits are light and flakey. Real maple syrup. It's warm and welcoming, just like the South at its best. I don't know about their discrimination in the past. Put seems like much of the South, they are working to do better.
Great pancakes with warm syrup, the best you can find anywhere in these USA.
We have enjoyed stopping at Cracker Barrel when traveling. Wish there was one closer to where we live. The greens are the best.

I've only been to Cracker Barrel one time and that was enough. I gained 10 pounds just reading the menu and could feel my arteries hardening at the same time. Yes, my grandmother DID cook this way, and died or heart disease and was obese. That's one family tradition I can do without.

But I attend a pulmonary rehab program with huge fans of Cracker Barrel (yes they ARE all overweight!). They love the kitsch and totally buy into the "we're just plain folks" schtick. And they love that country cooking.

I don't see Cracker Barrel as "southern" - far more as "country". And there are those who think if it's country, it's wholesome and good. Maybe yes, maybe no, but that kind of food is good for NO ONE.

So their violations of the Civil Rights Act wasn't enough to snap you out of the arrested development of your sentimental delusions?

Bless you. But the cultural reality level of Cracker Barrel is worse than McDonald's. Besides that both of them are terribly responsible for the disappearance of the great Amazon Rain Forest and our global protective ozone layer, their food is killing people. Check the ingredients on their five gallon drums of "gravy". It's a long paragraph of eight syllable words from a college chemistry class.

But most of all it's the consciousness level that's the heart-stopper. Not just the kitschy worthless junk for sale, but the Disneyesque wistful illusion of the old South and sweet days gone by. Not so sweet for the great grand children of the slaves that were refused service by the great grand children of the slave owners.

When I journey across states, it's either Cracker Barrel or Waffle House.  Love the comfy, unhealthy food and sweet tea.  With a head full of dreadlocks, I get my share of stares in some Cracker Barrels and Waffle Houses, but I'm always treated kindly, with respect, and humor by staff.  On a two week drive, I can gain 5 pounds eating in these establishments.  But I do this only once per year, so it's easy to shed the weight the following months.  However, I so look forward to the next road trip on which I can eat to my hearts content!
I understand they are going to open a Cracker Barrel at Cliven Bundy's ranch in Nevada. His sons were trying for a franchise in Oregon, but that didn't work out.

Agreed. (Although I confess I never liked their food anyway -- deep fried everything with overcooked vegetables flavoured with grease. Yuck.)

Add the racism and homophobia and, well, I'll just keep driving by, thank you.

Thank you, Mr. Kristoff for writing about this movie, which I definitely plan to see. We must keep this young woman's story in the headlines and in our thoughts, along with many others unfortunately. Another must-see eye-opening movie INDIA'S DAUGHTER shows just how widespread rape and misogyny REALLY is throughout the world.

Bush may have been mistaken in having the U.S. topple Saddam Hussein in Iraq, but the current refugee crisis are more directly linked to Obama's decisions regarding Libya and Syria.  Just look at where most of the refugees are coming from, i.e., not Iraq.  Then, there are all those refugees streaming over the southern border of the U.S., from Mexico.  These refugee crises began well after Bush left office, mainly the last few years.

We really need a two words. The ancient meaning of "honor" as reflected in these societies, the Koran, and the Old Testament was pride and power; the man is king and warrior and cannot have his rule questioned. It was not that long ago that a nobleman in royal England or France wouldn't have instantly imprisoned or slain a subject or woman in his domain who disobeyed. Women were once property everywhere. Our modern meaning or honor meaning self sacrifice and self restrain and protection of the weak is completely foreign to this old world. The whole developing world is at war with itself as modern honor strives to replace the old concepts. Meanwhile we are not doing a very good job of embodying modern honor when we torture, invade, and imprison while supporting despots and tyrants ourselves. Over a million people have died and 7 million displaced from Bush's war. Bin Laden could not have done nearly as much to create Al'Queda and ISIS as our own conduct has.

CB was also rated the worst place for homosexuals to work a few years ago, would I as a gay man enjoy a meal there? No I wouldn't and when on two occasions I have been travelling with my parents and they loving CB, go along for lunch being gay & a vegetarian internally and externally did not feel accommodated.  Let you wallet speak for you, it is in this country our most powerful voice.

I grew up in NY but my family did frequent road-trips to the Southwest.  Stuckey's was IT!!!  I was especially fascinated by the fake rubber Indian weapons and tom-tom drums adorned with fluorescent-colored feathers.

The author omits perhaps the most infamous era in Cracker Barrel history, the period before 1991 when the company's official written policy was to deny employment to gay and lesbian people, and to fire any employee discovered to be anything other than completely heterosexual.  The policy changed only after a New York teachers' pension fund purchased a large stake in the company and used its clout to remove the offensive policy.

I remember Cracker Barrel's homophobic firing of gay employees in the '90's. That the Justice Department had to act to end racial discrimination at Cracker Barrel doesn't surprise me at all. I haven't spent a dime in this retrograde business in 25 years.  And it will be a very cold day in Hades before I do so again (and the same is true for Chick Fil A).
the most recent fault you cite was over 10 years ago.  A lot can change in 10 yrs; I assume you have too.
I did have a bad meal there, several in fact. It's way too folksy/artificial for me. Not a first choice for me at all - had stopped there only out of necessity.

I am sorry but I wasn't able to keep them out or to legitimately disenfranchise them. I suggested all kinds of really crackpot solutions-a return to the British Empire or surrendering to Japan and allowing them to run the country. But , it seems even our former worst enemies,(now bestest best friends), no longer are interested in the kind of hegemony or empire they were once so enamored of. Mostly, all our former foes tell us that we should count our blessings and that America was the luckiest nation in the world to be both equidistant from too much of Europe and Asia and, to have had the best leaders and legislators for a time from FDR until Gen. Eisenhower. We ought to get another leader like Mr Roosevelt,(Either one of them), and we'd do fine.
Sorry, but God refused to put his oar in this one.

Frank, I don't know what you mean by "religion was integral to our country's founding."  Yes, Puritans came here to be able to practice their religion.  But the establishment of a religion was rather quickly dropped.  Although Pennsylvania was one of the last colonies to be settled, it grew very quickly with the influx of European immigrants seeking William Penn's religious freedom.  Virginia's statute of religious freedom pre-dated the Constitution.  Inserting a wall, so to speak, between church and state was considered a very important part of the Bill of Rights.  Jefferson, Washington, Adams, Madison, Hamilton were not particularly religious.  The modern GOP. the Evangelicals, and the Catholics (yes, the Catholic Church and its continued fight against women's medical care), on the other hand, all want all of us to follow their particular brand of beliefs  -- really, a completely un-American concept.  Which, very unfortunately, seems to be becoming an American concept.  Jefferson, Madison, William Penn, et al, are certainly turning over in their graves.

They are not burned, just sun-baked for 500 years. They can look black in the right light (see Franz Lanting's amazing photos). These trees were 300 years old when they died 500 years ago, as the shifting red dunes blocked off their access to water. Since then, the air is too dry for them to rot, so they stand. Wind and age have removed all the twigs and small branches, so they stand as humanlike twisted trunks, looking like they have bodies and arms. Their dancerlike poses are what makes them so compelling in photographs. Plus the starkness of the deep blue sky, and the thousand-foot red dunes that can be made to fill the horizon. Add the chalky flat desert floor, and you have some stunning colors. It is a photographer's paradise, because you can endlessly blend different ratios of white, red, blue, and the black silhouette trunks or their shadows, depending on your perspective and camera angle. The openness of the landscape lets you move about to compose the trees as any size or proportion of your frame that you wish. If Deadvlei were in the US, every photography class in the country would go there to teach perspective, framing, color theory, and composition.
It is a stunning place, that I would put as one of the 7 wonders of the natural world.

I agree that Namibia is a fascinating country--a land of wild and varied landscapes and desert-adapted animals, to say nothing of the humans who have scratched an existence from sometimes forbidding terrain over millennia.

But I've been in the Deadvlei, and I have to say that while the camel thorn acacias are all dead, I can't recall a single one "crisped to a charcoal stump". Did someone set fire to all of them in the past few years?

Sure, a travel peace. Travellers are not blind nor deaf, as far as I know. Nick above is right.

The country is breath taking indeed. But,. but...
The difference between, say, the seaside villas in Walvis Bay, and the living conditions inland, 15 kilmoeters from there...

"Did quite well as a colony of Germany"? Sure.
Germany did well too.. local history talks about "first genocide"...- even before the Turks and the Armenians. A dry run for a couple of decades later?

Needless to say I greatly enjoyed my visit there two months ago.

Quite well? You might not be familiar with the German genocide of the Herero and Nama people. Some of the stunning landscapes you stand on in Namibia were sites of this genocide (Waterberg Park, Shark Island in Luderitz). You can google this to learn more.

Namibia is a wonderful place to visit - stunning landscapes, very wild animals. But I find anyplace hard to visit without wanting to know at least a little bit about the people who live their and their history - and Namibia has a fascinating history to learn about and wonderful people to meet while you visit there on your travels.

Namibia in general and especially the remote areas this article focuses on has few people.

Why would this be surprising? There's not a lot of people living in Death Valley or the northslope of Alaska either but I'd be surprised to hear someone questioning a travel article that "avoided" talking about the numerous non-existent people there.

I've been there too long ago when South Africa controlled the place and Namibia was called Southwest Africa (or something like that). It's well worth the visit.

Frankly, I'm quite surprised that South Africa gets so many tourists who never extend their visit to neighboring Namibia, Botswana, Mozambique, or even the internal Swaziland. All of these (with the possible exception of Mozambique) are quite safe and filled with many natural marvels (certainly when compared with Johannesburg). A package combining stunning Cape Town, a safari, animal watching along the Durban coast with the cool mountains of Swaziland, the remoteness of Namibia, the delta in Botswana, and capping off with eating a freshly caught fish cooked on a grill for you on a beautiful Indian Ocean beach in Mozambique would be, for many, a trip of lifetime.

The first genocide of the 20th century was committed by the Germans in the colony now known as Namibia. Following an uprising by the indigenous Herero people, the German army set about to kill every Herero man, woman and child, combatant or not. The Germans succeeded in exterminating an estimated 80% of the Herero people. Can't really say that the area's inhabitants "did quite well" under German rule.
